article.headline: Berman says Barr ârepeatedly urgedâ him to resign as top SDNY prosecutor
article.body: WASHINGTON (AP) â The ousted U.S. attorney who was leading investigations into President Donald Trumpâs allies told the House Judiciary panel on Thursday that Attorney General William Barr ârepeatedly urgedâ him to resign during a hastily arranged meeting that sheds light on the extraordinary standoff surrounding his departure. Geoffrey Berman, the former federal prosecutor for the Southern District of New York, provided the committee with a detailed account behind closed doors of three days in June as he was pushed out, according to his opening statement, which was obtained by the Associated Press. Berman said Barr, over a 45-minute session at the Pierre Hotel in New York, âpressedâ him to step aside and take on a new job heading up the Justice Departmentâs Civil Division so the administration could install Jay Clayton, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to the top prosecutor post in Manhattan. âI told the attorney general that I was not interested,â Berman told the panel. Berman explained, âThere were important investigations in the office that I wanted to see through to completion.â He told Barr that, while he liked Clayton, he viewed the SEC commissioner as âan unqualified choiceâ for the job. âHe had had no criminal experience,â Berman said. Clayton reportedly has been a golf partner of Trumpâs on several occasions, including, according to the New York Times, just days before Barr sought Bermanâs resignation from SDNY. When Barr warned Berman that if he didnât go voluntarily he would be fired, âI told him that while I did not want to get fired, I would not resign,â Berman said. The Judiciary Committee interview, which was being transcribed for public release later, comes as the panel deepens its probe of politicization at the Justice Department. Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., has called Bermanâs dismissal âpart of a clear and dangerous patternâ of behavior by Barr. The panelâs Democratic majority is pursuing its investigation of the attorney general, who they say operates more like Trumpâs personal lawyer than the nationâs top law-enforcement official. Barr is set to testify before the committee later this month. The Southern District, known for its high-profile prosecutions, is where Berman oversaw several ongoing investigations of Trump associates, including some who figured prominently in the House impeachment inquiry of the president. Bermanâs office is looking into the business dealings of Rudy Giuliani, Trumpâs personal lawyer and a former New York mayor. It has also prosecuted Trumpâs former personal lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen, who went to prison for lying to Congress and campaign-finance crimes and was on Thursday returned to federal prison days after the New York Post published photos of him at a restaurant. The closed-door interview with Berman spanned three hours. He was not expected to disclose information about the investigations into Trumpâs circle, but rather to discuss only his removal, according to a person familiar with the proceeding who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss it. He arrived without a lawyer. The session comes as the Capitol remains partially shut down during the COVID-19 crisis. A handful of lawmakers, but not all of those on the panel, attended. Berman, a registered Republican and reportedly a donor to Trumpâs 2016 campaign, was tapped by the administration in 2018 as the U.S. attorney for SDNY. He ultimately agreed to step down from his post, but only after being assured his officeâs probes of Trumpâs circle would continue. As he sat alone before the committee on Thursday, Berman told the panel of the series of events that started with an email from Barrâs office requesting the meeting, apparently on June 18. He said he was not told what it was about. When he arrived at Barrâs hotel suite the next day, there âwere sandwiches on the table, but nobody ate.â Barr told him he wanted to make changes at the office. Berman resisted, saying he âlovedâ his job and asked if Barr was âdissatisfiedâ with his performance. Barr assured him the move was solely because SEC head Clayton wanted to relocate to New York and the administration wanted to âkeep him on the team.â Before taking the reins at the SEC, Clayton had been a well-connected Wall Street lawyer who represented and advised a number of major companies, including Goldman Sachs, Barclays, Deutsche Bank and UBS. Back and forth it went on that Friday at the Pierre, with Barr saying the move would be good for Bermanâs rÃ©sumÃ© and eventual return to the private sector, Berman said. Berman would âonly have to sit thereâ for five months until the presidential election determined next steps, Barr said. He told Berman it would be an opportunity to accumulate a âbook of businessâ â clients â to bring to a private firm. As Berman remained unmoved, Barr told him âhe was trying to think of other jobs in the administrationâ that might be of interest. âI said that there was no job offer that would entice me to resign from my position,â Berman recalled. Late that Friday the Justice Department issued a statement saying Berman was stepping down, launching the standoff. Berman issued his own statement saying he had âno intention of resigning.â He showed up for work Saturday. On Saturday night, Barr publicly released a letter saying he had been fired by the president. At the time, Trump told reporters it was âall up to the attorney general,â adding, âI wasnât involved.â Berman told the House panel the letter also contained a âcritical concessionâ from Barr. In it, Barr stated that Bermanâs hand-picked deputy would take over as acting U.S. attorney until the permanent successor was in place. Berman said that with âfull confidenceâ the work of the office would continue, âI decided to step down and not litigate my removal.â Berman had worked from 1987 to 1990 for the independent counsel who investigated the administration of President Ronald Reagan in the Iran-contra affair. He previously served in the SDNY office as an assistant U.S. attorney from 1990 to 1994 before joining private practice, including time at the same firm as Giuliani. He reportedly met with Trump before being assigned as the top federal prosecutor job in Manhattan, after Trumpâs ouster of Preet Preet Bharara in 2017. Bharara, a federal prosecutor appointed to the SDNY post by President Barack Obama, announced his own firing in March 2017, shortly after Trump took office. SDNY has probed Trumpâs inaugural fundraising and overseen the prosecution of two Florida businessmen, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, who were associates of Giuliani and tied to the Ukraine impeachment investigation.
